long-description.p: Loughshinny is a tiny fishing-village on the coast of County Dublin, about midway between the larger villages of Rush and Skerries.

The area is well known to geologists from Dublin for the fine exposures of contorted strata exhibited in the neighbouring cliffs. These exposures form part of an extensive coast-section of Carboniferous rocks which may be followed, with a few interruptions, for about 8 kilometers from Rush on the south to Skerries on the north.

The geology of Loughshinny is remarkable in that it of layers of grey limestone and black shales formed about 300 million years ago.
The visible folding of the rocks happened later, about 290 million years ago.
This process resulted in chevron or zigzag folds the axial planes of the folds (anticlines and synclines) tilt to the south with overturned northern limbs, Some fossils, crinoids, bivalves and corals, can be seen in some of the beds.
All of which can be seen a short walk from Loughshinny Harbour.

The rocks that occur in County Dublin are all, with the exception of the latest Pleistocene glacial tills, of Paleozoic age having been formed between 590 and 350 million years ago during the Cambrian to Carboniferous periods.

p.b: Geological periods in the Paleozoic Era:

long-description.p: To log your visit please answer the following questions:

ul.li: What is the name of the county that the Devonian period is named after?
The Permian period was named after which kingdom?
Who named the Permian period and when was it named?
Estimate the length and height of the folds at the above coordinates.
A photo is also required which must show you or your gps on Loughshinny beach.

long-description.p: Please post the photo and email me the answers to the questions asked. Logs that do not include all the answers will be deleted.

You can check local tide times Here and
Here

ul.li:
2010-05-04T19:00:00Z : Found it by Wilddrude
Went to this nice beach with Geo Chief on our last day of vacation. Very nice place.
Thanks for the cache and greetings from Germany, Wilddrude

2010-05-04T19:00:00Z : Found it by Geo Chief
We had luck with the tides at our last day in Ireland and so we had a chance to visit this nice place. It was a very intersting walk along the folds with some sea birds, mussels and an a long talking with a local walker.
Thanks for the quick response and greetings from Germany Geo Chief
[This entry was edited by Geo Chief on Friday, May 07, 2010 at 1:10:29 PM.]

2010-04-20T19:00:00Z : Found it by dsquaredd2
Biggest caching day for D2D2 today with a cache run with the owner, Windsockers! We went on a circuit beginning with Newgrange and ending in the Skerries finding and maintaining caches. A fun day, each location was unique. Trading answers for the photo. This was the twenty-third. TFTC!

2010-01-13T20:00:00Z : Found it by nisse_perlemo
Found this geological formation despite adverse weather conditions. Wellingtons and coats were essential equipment! TFTC

2010-01-13T20:00:00Z : Found it by Kolingen
A very windy day by the sea and we climbed the wet rocks. Puh! Interesting cliffs. T4TC
# 23, 2010
# 678
[This entry was edited by Kolingen on Wednesday, January 13, 2010 at 11:30:34 AM.]

groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:name: Loughshinny Folds
groundspeak:cache.groundspeak:long_description:
Loughshinny is a tiny fishing-village on the coast of County Dublin, about midway between the larger villages of Rush and Skerries.

The area is well known to geologists from Dublin for the fine exposures of contorted strata exhibited in the neighbouring cliffs. These exposures form part of an extensive coast-section of Carboniferous rocks which may be followed, with a few interruptions, for about 8 kilometers from Rush on the south to Skerries on the north.

The geology of Loughshinny is remarkable in that it of layers of grey limestone and black shales formed about 300 million years ago.
The visible folding of the rocks happened later, about 290 million years ago.
This process resulted in chevron or zigzag folds the axial planes of the folds (anticlines and synclines) tilt to the south with overturned northern limbs, Some fossils, crinoids, bivalves and corals, can be seen in some of the beds.
All of which can be seen a short walk from Loughshinny Harbour.

The rocks that occur in County Dublin are all, with the exception of the latest Pleistocene glacial tills, of Paleozoic age having been formed between 590 and 350 million years ago during the Cambrian to Carboniferous periods.

Geological periods in the Paleozoic Era:

  • Permian 248 – 286 million years
  • Carboniferous 286 – 360 million years
  • Devonian 360 – 408 million years
  • Silurian 408 – 438 million years
  • Ordovician 438 – 505 million years
  • Cambrian 505 – 590 million years

To log your visit please answer the following questions:

  • What is the name of the county that the Devonian period is named after?
  • The Permian period was named after which kingdom?
  • Who named the Permian period and when was it named?
  • Estimate the length and height of the folds at the above coordinates.
  • A photo is also required which must show you or your gps on Loughshinny beach.

Please post the photo and email me the answers to the questions asked. Logs that do not include all the answers will be deleted.

This cache is tidal dependant

You can check local tide times Here and Here

Additional Waypoints

PK1K7QG - GC1K7QG Parking
N 53° 32.834 W 006° 04.900

Biggest caching day for D2D2 today with a cache run with the owner, Windsockers! We went on a circuit beginning with Newgrange and ending in the Skerries finding and maintaining caches. A fun day, each location was unique. Trading answers for the photo. This was the twenty-third. TFTC!
